div1.head: ADVERTISEMENT.
div1.p: THE travels of an Englishman throughout Europe, and even in some parts of Asia, to soften the sorrows of the Prisoner, excited in the mind of the Author the subject of the following pages, which, formed into a dramatic story, have produced from the Theatre a profit far exeeeding the usual pecuniary advantages arising from a successful Comedy.

The uncertainty in what part of the East the hero of the present piece was (at the time it was written) dispensing his benevolence, caused the Writer, after many researches and objections, to fix the scene on the island of Sumatra, where the English settlement, the system of government, and every description of the manners of the people, reconcile the incidents of the Play to the strictest degree of probability.

lg.l: HOW say you, critic Gods Galleries. and you below Pit.
Are you all friends?—or here—and there—a foe?
Come to protect your literary trade,
Which Mrs. Scribble dares again invade—
But know you not—in all the fair ones do,
'Tis not to please themselves alone—but you.
Then who so churlish, or so cynic grown,
Would wish to change a simper for a frown?
Or who so jealous of their own dear quill,
Would point the paragraph her fame to kill?
Yet such there are, in this all-scribbling town,
And men of letters too—of some renown,
Who sicken at all merit but their own.
But sure 'twere more for Wit's—for Honour's sake,
To make the Drama's race—the give and take.
My hint I see's approv'd—so pray begin it,
And praise us—roundly for the good things in it,
Nor let severity our faults expose,
When godlike Homer's self was known to doze.
But of the piece—Methinks I hear you hint,
Some dozen lines or more should give the tint—
"Tell how Sir John with Lady Betty's maid
"Is caught intriguing at a masquerade;
"Which Lady Betty, in a jealous fit,
"Resents by flirting with Sir Ben—the cit.
"Whose three-feet spouse, to modish follies bent,
"Mistakes a six-feet Valet—for a Gent.
"Whilst Miss, repugnant to her Guardian's plan,
"Elopes in Breeches with her fav'rite man."
Such are the hints we read in Roscius' days,
By way of Prologue ushered in their plays.
But we, like Ministers and cautious spies,
In secret measures think—the merit lies.
Yet shall the Muse thus far unveil the plot—
This play was tragi-comically got,
Those sympathetic sorrows to impart
Which harmonize the feelings of the heart;
And may at least this humble merit boast,
A structure founded on fair Fancy's coast.
With you it rests that judgement to proclaim,
Which in the world must raise or sink it's fame.
Yet ere her judges sign their last report,
'Tis you [to the boxes] must recommend her to the Court;
Whose smiles, like Cynthia, in a winter's night,
Will cheer our wand'rer with a gleam of light.

set.p: ACT I. SCENE, The Island of Sumatra, in the East Indies.

div1.head: SUCH THINGS ARE. A PLAY. IN FIVE ACTS.

div3.head: SCENE I. A Parlour at Sir Luke Tremor's.
div3.stage: Enter Sir Luke, followed by Lady Tremor.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: I TELL you, Madam, you are two and thirty.

sp.speaker: Lady Tremor.
sp.p: I tell you, Sir, you are mistaken.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Why, did not you come over from England exactly sixteen years ago?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Not so long.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Have not we been married the tenth of next April sixteen years?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Not so long.—

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Did you not come over the year of the great Eclipse? answer me that.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I don't remember it.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p:
But I do—and shall remember it as long as I live—the first time I saw you, was in the garden of the Dutch Envoy; you were looking through a glass at the sun—I immediately began to make love to you, and the whole affair was
settled while the eclipse lasted—just one hour eleven minutes, and three seconds.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: But what is all this to my age?

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Because I know you were at that time near seventeen—and without one qualification except your youth—and not being a Mullatto.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Sir Luke, Sir Luke, this is not to be borne—

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Oh! yes—I forgot—you had two letters of recommendation, from two great families in England.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Letters of recommendation!

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Yes; your character—that, you know, is all the fortune we poor Englishmen, situated in India, expect with a wife who crosses the sea at the hazard of her life, to make us happy.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: And what but our characters would you have us bring? Do you suppose any lady ever came to India, who brought along with her, friends, or fortune?

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: No, my dear—and what is worse—she seldom leaves them behind, either.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: No matter, Sir Luke—but if I delivered to you a good character—

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Yes, my dear you did—and if you were to ask me for it again, I can't say I could give it you.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: How uncivil! how unlike are your manners to the manners of my Lord Flint.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Ay—you are never so happy as when you have an opportunity of expressing your admiration of him—a disagreeable, nay, a very dangerous man—one is never sure of one's self in his presence—he carries every thing he hears to the ministers of our suspicious Sultan—and I feel my head shake whenever I am in his company.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: How different does his Lordship appear to me—to me he is all politesse.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Politesse! how shou'd you underderstand what is real politesse? You know your education was very much confined.—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: And if it was confined——I beg, Sir Luke, you will one time or other cease these reflections—you know they are what I can't bear! [walks about in a passion.] pray, does not his Lordship continually assure me, I might be taken for a Countess, were it not for a certain little groveling toss I have caught with my head—and a certain little confined hitch in my walk? both which I learnt of you—learnt by looking so much at you.—

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: And now if you don't take care, by looking so much at his Lordship, you may catch some of his defects.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I know of very few he has.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: I know of many—besides those he assumes.—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Assumes!!——

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Yes; do you suppose he is as forgetful as he pretends to be? no, no—but because he is a favourite with the Sultan, and all our great men at court, he thinks it genteel or convenient to have no memory—and yet I'll answer for it, he has one of the best in the universe.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I don't believe your charge.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Why, though he forgets his appointments with his tradesmen, did you ever hear of his forgetting to go to court when a place was to be disposed of? Did he ever make a blunder, and send a bribe to a man out of power? Did he ever forget to kneel before the Prince of this Island—or to look in his highness's presence like the statue of Patient-resignation in humble expectation?—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Dear, Sir Luke——

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p:
Sent from his own country in his very infancy, and brought up in the different
courts of petty, arbitrary Princes here in Asia; he is the slave of every great man, and the tyrant of every poor one.—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: "Petty Princes!"—'tis well his highness our Sultan does not hear you.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: 'Tis well he does not—don't you repeat what I say—but you know how all this fine country is harrassed and laid waste by a set of Princes, Sultans, as they style themselves, and I know not what—who are for ever calling out to each other "that's mine," and "that's mine;"—and "you have no business here"—and "you have no business there"—and "I have business every where;" [Strutting] then "give me this,"—and "give me that;" and "take this, and take that."

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: A very elegant description truly.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Why, you know 'tis all matter of fact—and Lord Flint, brought up from his youth amongst these people, has not one trait of an Englishman about him—he has imbibed all this country's cruelty, and I dare say wou'd mind no more seeing me hung up by my thumbs—or made to dance upon a red-hot gridiron——

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: That is one of the tortures I never heard of!—O! I shou'd like to see that of all things!

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Yes—by keeping this man's company, you'll soon be as cruel as he is—he will teach you every vice—a consequential—grave—dull—and yet with that degree of levity, that dares to pay his addresses to a woman, even before her husband's face.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Did not you say, this minute, his Lordship had not a trait of his own country about him?—

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Well, well—as you say, that last is a trait of his own country.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Lord Flint.—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: My Lord, I am extremely glad to see you—we were just mentioning your name.—

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Were you, indeed, Madam? You do me great honour.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: No, my Lord—no great honour.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Pardon me, Sir Luke.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: But, I assure you, my Lord, what I said, did myself a great deal of honour.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, and I'll acquaint your Lordship what it was.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Why, you wou'd not inform against me sure! Do you know what would be the consequence? My head must answer it.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Nay, Sir Luke, I insist upon knowing.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Hush—hush——no, my Lord, pray excuse me—your Lordship perhaps may think what I said did not come trom my heart; and I assure you, upon my honour, it did.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: O, yes—that I am sure it did.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: I am extremely obliged to you.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: O, no, my Lord, not at all—not at all.— [aside to her.] I'll be extremely obliged to you, if you will hold your tongue—Pray, my Lord, are you engaged out to dinner to-day? for her Ladyship and I dine out.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, and we should be happy to find your Lordship of the party.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: "Engaged out to dinner"?—egad very likely—very likely—but if I am—I have positively forgotten where.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: We are going to—

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p:
No—I think (now you put me in mind
of it) I think I have company to dine with me—I am either going out to dinner, or have company to dine with me; but I really can't tell which—however, my people know——but I can't call to mind.—

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Perhaps your Lordship has dined; can you recollect that?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: No, no—I have not dined——what's o'clock?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Perhaps, my Lord, you have not breakfasted.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: O, yes, I've breakfasted—I think so—but upon my word these things are very hard to remember.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: They are indeed, my Lord—and I wish all my family wou'd entirely forget them.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: What did your Ladyship say was o'clock?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Exactly twelve, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Bless me! I ought to have been some where else then—an absolute engagement.—I have broke my word—a positive appointment.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Shall I send a servant?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: No, no, no, no—by no means—it can't be helped now—and they know my unfortunate failing—besides, I'll beg their pardon, and I trust that will be ample satistaction.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: You are very good, my Lord, not to leave us.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: I cou'd not think of leaving you so soon, Madam—the happiness I enjoy here is such—

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: And very likely were your Lordship to go away now, you might never recollect to come again.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: A Gentleman, Sir, just come from on board an English vessel, says, he has letters to present to you.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Shew him in— [Exit Servant.]He has brought his character too, I suppose—and left it behind, too, I suppose.

div3.stage: Enter Mr. Twineall, in a fashionable undress.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Sir Luke, I have the honour of presenting to you, [Gives letters] one from my Lord Cleland—one from Sir Thomas Shoestring—one from Colonel Fril.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Who in the name of wonder have my friends recommended?— [reads while Lord Flint and the Lady talk apart] No—as I live, he is a gentleman, and the son of a Lord— [going to Lady Tremor.] My dear, that is a gentleman, notwithstanding his appearance—don't laugh—but let me introduce you to him.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: A gentleman! certainly—I did not look at him before—but now I can perceive it.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p:
Mr. Twineall, give me leave to introduce Lady Tremor to you, and my Lord Flint—this, my Lord, is the Honourable Mr. Twineall from England, who will do me the favour to remain in my house, till he is settled to his mind in some post here. [They bow.] I beg your pardon, Sir, for the somewhat cool reception Lady Tremor and I gave you at first—but I dare say her Ladyship was under the same mistake as myself—and I must own I took you at first fight for something very different from the person you prove to be—for really no English ships have arrived in this harbour for
these five years past, and the dress of us English gentlemen is so much altered fince that time—

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: But, I hope, Sir Luke, if it is, the alteration meets with your approbation.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: O! to be sure—it is extremely elegant and becoming.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Yes, my dear, I don't doubt but you think so; for I remember you used to make your favourite monkey wear just such a jacket, when he went out a visiting.

sp.speaker: Twin.
sp.p: Was he your favourite, Madam?—Sir, you are very obliging.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: My Lord, if it were possible for your Lordship to call to your remembrance such a trifle—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Dear Sir Luke—

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Egad, I believe I do call to my remembrance— [Gravely considering.]—Not, I assure you, Sir, that I perceive any great resemblance—or, if it was so—I dare say it is merely in the dress——which I must own strikes me as most ridiculous—very ridiculous indeed.——

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: My Lord!

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: I beg pardon, if I have said any thing that——Lady Tremor, what did I say?——make my apology, if I have said any thing improper—you know my unhappy failing.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Sir, his Lordship has made a mistake in the word "ridiculous," which I am sure he did not mean to say—but he is apt to make use of one word for another—his Lordship has been so long out of England, that he may be said in some measure to have forgotten his native language.

div3.stage: [His Lordship all this time appears consequentially absent.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p:
And you have perfectly explained, Madam—indeed I ought to have been convinced,
without your explanation, that if his Lordship made use of the word ridiculous (even intentionally) that the word had now changed its former sense, and was become a mode to express satisfaction—or his Lordship wou'd not have made use of it in the very forcible manner he did, to a perfect stranger.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: What, Mr. Twineall, have you new modes, new fashions for words too in England, as well as for dresses?—and are you equally extravagant in their adoption?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I never heard, Sir Luke, but that the fashion of words varied, as well as the fashion of every thing else.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: But what is most extraordinary—we have now a fashion in England, of speaking without any words at all.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, how is that?

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Ay, do, Mr. Twineall, teach my wife, and I shall be very much obliged to you—it will be a great accomplishment. Even you, my Lord, ought to be attentive to this fashion.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Why, Madam, for instance, when a gentleman is asked a question which is either troublesome or improper to answer, you don't say you won't answer it, even though you speak to an inferior——but you say——"really it appears to me e-e-e-e-e— [mutters and shrugs]—that is—mo-mo-mo-mo-mo— [mutters]—if you see the thing—for my part——te-te-te-te——and that's all I can tell about it at persent.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: And you have told nothing!

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Nothing upon earth.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: But mayn't one guess what you mean?

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: O, yes—perfectly at liberty to guess.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Well, I'll be shot if I could guess.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p:
And again—when an impertinent pedant
asks you a question that you know nothing about, and it may not be convenient to say so—you answer boldly, "why really, Sir, my opinion is, that the Greek poet—he-he-he-he— [mutters]—we-we-we-we—you see—if his idea was—and if the Latin translator—mis-mis-mis-mis— [shrugs]——that I shou'd think—in my humble opinion—but the Doctor may know better than I."——

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: The Doctor must know very little else.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Or in case of a duel, where one does not care to say who was right, or who was wrong—you answer—"This, Sir, is the state of the matter—Mr. F—came first—te-te-te-te—on that—be-be-be-be—if the other—in short— [whispers]—whis-whis-whis-whis"—

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: There, now you have it—there 'tis—but don't say a word about it—or, if you do—don't say it come from me."—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Why, you have not told a word of the story!

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: But that your auditor must not say to you—that's not the fashion—he never tells you that——he may say—"You have not made yourself perfectly clear;"—or he may say—" He must have the matter more particularly pointed out somewhere else;"—but that is all the auditor can say with good breeding.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: A very pretty method indeed to satisfy one's curiosity!

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Mr. Haswell.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: This is a countryman of ours, Mr. Twineall, and a very good man I assure you.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Mr. Haswell, how do you do?

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: Sir Luke, I am glad to see you.——Lady Tremor, how do you do?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: O, Mr. Haswell, I am extremely glad you are come—here is a young adventurer just arrived from England, who has been giving us such a strange account of all that's going on there.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: Sir, you are welcome to India. [Sir Luke whispers Haswell. Indeed!—his son.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Do, Mr. Haswell, talk to him—he can give you great information.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: I am glad of it—I shall then hear many things I am impatient to become acquainted with. [Goes up to Twineall.] Mr. Twineall, I have the honour of knowing his Lordship, your father, extremely well—he holds his seat in Parliament still, I presume?

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: He does, Sir.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: And your uncle, Sir Charles?

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Both, Sir—both in Parliament still.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, has any act in behalf of the poor clergy taken place yet?

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: In behalf of the poor clergy, Sir?—I'll tell you—l'll tell you, Sir.——As to that act—concerning— [shrugs and mutters]—em-em-em-em—the Committee—em-em—ways and means—hee-hee—I assure you, Sir—te-te-te— [Sir Luke, Lady, and Lord Flint laugh. My father and my uncle both think so, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: Think how, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Nay, that's not good breeding—you must ask no more questions.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Because—we-we-we-we— [mimicks]—he knows nothing about it.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: What, Sir—not know?

sp.speaker: Twi
sp.p: Yes, Sir, perfectly acquainted with every thing that passes in the house—but I assure you, that when they come to be reported——but, Sir Luke, now permit me, in my turn, to make a few inquiries concerning the state of this country.

div3.stage: [Sir Luke starts, and fixes his eyes suspiciously on Lord Flint.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Why, one does not like to speak much about the country one lives in—but, Mr. Haswell, you have been visiting our encampments; you may tell us what is going on there.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Pray, Mr. Haswell, is it true that the Sultan cut off the head of one of his wives the other day because she said "I won't?"

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Do, my dear, be silent.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I won't.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: O, that the Sultan had you instead of me!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: And with my head off, I suppose?

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: No, my dear; in that state, I shou'd have no objection to you myself.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Now, I'll frighten you ten times more.—But, Mr. Haswell, I am told there are many persons suspected of disaffection to the present Sultan, who have been lately, by his orders, arrested, and sold to slavery, notwithstanding there was no proof against them produced.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: Proof!——in a State such as this, the charge is quite sufficient.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.stage:
[In apparent agonies, wishing to turn
the discourse.]
sp.p: Well, my Lord, and how does your Lordship find yourself this afternoon?—this morning, I mean—Bless my soul! why I begin to be as forgetful as your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: How I pity the poor creatures!

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Take care what you say before that tool of state—look at him, and tremble for your head.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Look at him, and tremble for yours—and so, Mr. Haswell, all this is true?—and some people, of consequence too, I am told, dragged from their homes, and sent to slavery merely on suspicion?

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: Yet, less do I pity those, than some, whom prisons and dungeons crammed before, are yet prepared to receive.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Mr. Haswell, such is the Sultan's pleasure.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Will your Lordship take a turn in the garden? it looks from this door very pleasant;—does not it?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: But pray, Mr. Haswell, has not the Sultan sent for you to attend at his palace this morning?

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: He has, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: There! I heard he had, but Sir Luke said not.—I am told he thinks himself under the greatest obligations to you.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: The report has flattered me—but if his highness shou'd think himself under obligations, I can readily point a way, by which he may acquit himself of them.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: In the mean time, I am sure, you feel for those poor sufferers.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p:
Sir Luke, good morning to you—I call'd upon some trifling business, but I have out-staid my time, and therefore
fore I'll call again in a couple of hours—Lady Tremor, good morning—my Lord—Mr. Twine-all—

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Sir Luke, your garden does look so divinely beautiful—

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Come, my Lord, will you take a turn in it? Come Mr. Twineall—come my dear— [taking ber hand.] I can't think what business Mr. Haswell has to speak to me upon—for my part, I am quite a plain man—and busy myself about no one's affairs, except my own—but I dare say your Lordship has forgot all we have been talking about.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: If you permit me, Sir Luke, I'll hand the Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Certainly, my Lord, if you please—come, Mr. Twineall, and I'll conduct you.

div3.head: SCENE I. An Apartment at Sir Luke Tremor's.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: MY dear friend, after so long a separation, how gland I am to meet you!—but how devilish unlucky that you shou'd, on the very day of my arrival, be going to set sail for another part of the world! yet before you go, I must beg a favour of you—you know Sir Luke and his family perfectly well, I dare say?

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: I think so—I have been in his house near six years.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: The very person on earth I wanted!—Sir Luke has power here, I suppose?—a word from him might do a man some service perhaps?

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Why, yes; I don't know a man that has more influence at a certain place.

sp.speaker: Twin.
sp.p: And her Ladyship seems a very clever gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Very.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: And I have a notion they think me very clever.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: I dare say they do.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Yes—but I mean very clever.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: No doubt!

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p:
But, my dear friend, you must help me to make them think better of me still—and when
my fortune is made, I'll make yours—for when I once become acquainted with people's dispositions, their little weaknesses, foibles and faults, I can wind, twist, twine, and get into the corner of every one's heart, and lie so snug, they can't know I'm there, till they want to pull me out, and find 'tis impossible.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Excellent talent!

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Is not it? and now, my dear friend, do you inform me of the secret dispositions, and propensities of every one in this family, and of all their connections.—What Lady values herself upon one qualification, and what Lady upon another?—What Gentleman will like to be told of his accomplishments? or his daughter's?—or of his horses? or of his dogs?—now, my dear Ned, acquaint me with all this—and within a fortnight I will become the most necessary rascal——not a creature shall know how to exist without me.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Why such a man as you ought to have made your fortune in England.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: No—my father, and my three uncles monopolized all the great men themselves; and wou'd never introduce me where I was likely to become their rival—This—this is the very spot for me to display my genius—But then I must penetrate the people first—and you will kindly save me that trouble.—Come, give me all their characters—all short, all I am to praise—and all I am to avoid praising,—in order to endear myself to them. [Takes out tablets.] Come—begin with Sir Luke.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Sir Luke—values himself more upon personal bravery, than upon any thing else.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Thank you, my dear friend—thank you. [Writes] Was he ever in the army?

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Oh yes—besieged a capital fortress, a few years ago—and now, the very name of a battle or a great general tickles his vanity, and he takes all the praises you can lavish upon the subject as compliments to himself.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Thank you—thank you a thousand times— [Writes.] I'll mention a battle very soon.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Not directly.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: O, no—let me alone for time and place—go on, my friend—go on—her Ladyship—

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Descended from the ancient kings of Scotland.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: You don't say so!

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: And though she is so nicely scrupulous as never to mention the word genealogy, yet I have seen her agitation so great, when the advantages of high birth have been extoll'd, she could scarcely withhold her sentiments of triumph; which in order to disguise, she has assumed a disdain for all "vain titles—empty sounds—and idle pomp."

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Thank you—thank you—this is a most excellent trait of the Lady's— [Writes.] "Pedigree of the kings of Scotland?" O, I have her at once.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Yet do it nicely—oblique touches, rather than open explanations.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Let me alone for that.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: She has, I know, in her possession—but I dare say she wou'd not show it you, nay, on the contrary, would even affect to be highly offended, if you were to mention it—and yet it certainly would flatter her, to know you were acquainted with her having it.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: What—what—what is it?

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p:
A large old-fashioned wig—which Malcolm
the third or fourth, her great ancestor, wore when he was crowned at Scone, in the year——

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: I'll mention it.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Take care.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: O, let me alone for the manner

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: She'll pretend to be angry.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: That I am prepared for.—Pray who is my Lord Flint?

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: A deep man—and a great favourite at court.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Indeed!—how am I to please him?

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: By insinuations against the present Sultan.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: With all his pretended attachment, his heart——

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Are you sure of it?

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Sure:—he blinds Sir Luke, (who by the bye is no great politician) but I know his Lordship—and if he thought he was sure of his ground—(and he thinks he shall be sure of it soon)—then—

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: I'll insinuate myself and join his party—but, in the mean time, preserve good terms with Sir Luke, in case any thing shou'd fall in my way there.—Who is Mr. Haswell?

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: He pretends to be a man of principle and sentiment—flatter him on that.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: The easieft thing in the world—no people like flattery better than such as he.—They will bear even to hear their vices praised.—I will myself undertake to praise the vices of a man of sentiment till he shall think them so many virtues.—You have mentioned no Ladies, but the Lady of the house yet.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p:
There is no other Lady, except a pretty girl who came over from England, about two years ago, for a husband, and not succeeding in another
part of the country, is now recommended to this house—and has been here three or four months.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Let me alone, to please her.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Let me alone, to please her.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Yes—I believe you are skilled.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: For the art of flattery, no one more.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: But damn it—it is not a liberal art.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: It is a great science, notwithstanding—and studied, at present, by all the connoisseurs.—Zounds! I have staid a long time—I can't attend to any more characters at present—Sir Luke and his Lady will think me inattentive, if I don't join them—Shall I see you again?—if not—I wish you a pleasant voyage—I'll make the most of what you have told me—you'll hear I'm a great man—God bless you!—good bye!—you'll hear I'm a great man.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p:
And, if I am not mistaken, I shall hear you are turned out of the house before to-morrow morning. O, Twineall! exactly the reverse of every character have you now before you—the greatest misfortune in the life of Sir Luke has been, flying from his army in the midst of an engagement, and a most humiliating degradation in consequence, which makes him so feelingly alive on the subject of a battle, that nothing but his want of courage can secure my friend Twineall's life for venturing to name the subject—then Lord Flint, firmly attached to the interest of the Sultan, will be all on fire, when he hears of open disaffection—but most of all her Ladyship! whose father was a grocer, and uncle, a noted advertising "Periwig-maker on a new construction." She will run mad to hear of births, titles, and long pedigrees.—Poor Twineall! little dost thou think what is prepared for thee.—There is Mr. Haswell too—but to him have I sent you to be reclaimed—to him,—who, free from faults, or even foibles,
of his own, has yet more potently the blessing given, of tenderness for ours.

div3.head: SCENE II. The inside of a Prison.
div3.stage: Several Prisoners dispersed in different situations.
Enter Keeper and Haswell with lights.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: This way, Sir—the prisons this way are more extensive still—you seem to feel for these unthinking men—but they are a set of unruly people, whom no severity can make such as they ought to be.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: And wou'd not gentleness, or mercy, do you think, reclaim them?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: That I can't say—we never try those means in this part of the world—that man yonder, suspected of disaffection, is sentenced to be here for life, unless his friends can lay down a large sum by way of penalty, which he finds they cannot do, and he is turned melancholy.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: Who is that?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: He has been try'd for heading an insurrection, and acquitted.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: What keeps him here?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Fees due to the Court—a debt contracted while he proved his innocence.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: Lead on, my friend—let us go to some other part.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: In this ward, we are going to, are the prisoners, who by some small reserve—some little secreted stock when they arrived—or by the bounty of some friend who visit them——or such-like fortunate circumstance, are in a less dismal place.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: Lead on.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: But stop—put on this cloak, for, before we arrive at the place I mention, we must pass a damp vault, which to those who are not used to it— [Haswell puts on the cloak]—or will you postpone your visit?

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: No—go on.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Alas! who wou'd suppose you had been used to see such places!—you look concerned—vext to see the people suffer—I wonder you shou'd come, when you seem to think so much about them.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: Oh! that, that is the very reason.

div3.stage: [Zedan, a tawny Indian Prisoner, follows them, stealing out, as if intent on something.]
Two Prisoners walk slowly down the Stage.

sp.speaker: 1st Pris.
sp.p: Who is this man?

sp.speaker: 2d Pris.
sp.p: From Britain—I have seen him once before.

sp.speaker: 1st Pris.
sp.p: He looks pale—he has no heart.

sp.speaker: 2d Pris.
sp.p: I believe, a pretty large one.

sp.speaker: Zed.
sp.p: Brother, a word with you. [To the Ist Prisoner, the other retires] as the stranger and our keeper passed by the passage, a noxious vapour put out the light, and as they groped along I purloined this from the stranger— [Shews a pocket-book]see it contains two notes will pay our ransom.

sp.speaker: 1st Pris.
sp.p: A treasure—our certain ransom!

sp.speaker: Zed.
sp.p: Liberty! our wives, our children, and our friends, will these papers purchase.

sp.speaker: 1st Pris.
sp.p: What a bribe! our keeper may rejoice too.

sp.speaker: Zed.
sp.p: And then the pleasure it will be to hear the stranger fret, and complain for his loss!—O, how my heart loves to see forrow!—Misery such as I have known, on men who spurn me—who treat me as if (in my own Island) I had no friends that loved me—no servants that paid me honour—no children that revered me—who forget I am a husband—a father—nay, a man.—

sp.speaker: 1st Pris.
sp.p: Conceal your thoughts—conceal your treature too—or the Briton's complaint—

sp.speaker: Zed.
sp.p: Will be in vain—our keeper will conclude the bribe must come to him, at laft—and therefore make no great search for it—here, in the corner of my belt [Puts up the pocket-book] twill be secure—Come this way, and let us indulge our pleasant prospect.

div3.head: SCENE III. Another part of the Prison.
div3.stage: A kind of sopha with an old man sleeping upon it—Elvirus sitting attentively by him.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: That young man, you see there, watching his aged father as he sleeps, by the help of fees gains his admission—and he never quits the place, except to go and purchase cordials for the old man, who, (though healthy and strong when he first became a prisoner) is now become ill and languid.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: Are they from Europe?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: No—but descended from Europeans—see how the youth holds his father's hand!—I have sometimes caught him bathing it with tears.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: I'll speak to the young man.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p:
He will speak as soon as he sees me—he has sent a petition to the Sultan about his father,
and never fails to inquire if a reply is come.
Sir, do you come from the Court? has the Sultan received my humble supplication? Can you tell?—softly—let not my father hear you speak.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: I come but as a stranger, to see the prisoh.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: No answer yet, keeper?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: No—I told you it was in vain to write—they never read petitions sent from prisons—their hearts are hardened to such worn-out tales of sorrow.
sp.stage: [Elvirus turns towards his Father and weeps.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: Pardon me, Sir—but what is the request you are thus denied?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Behold my father! but three months has he been confined here; and yet—unless he breathes a purer air—O, if you have influence at Court, Sir, pray represent what passes in this dreary prison—what passes in my heart.——My supplication is to remain a prisoner here, while my father, released, shall be permitted to retire to humble life; and never more take arms in a cause the Sultan may suspect—which engagement broken, my life shall be the forfeit.—Or if the Sultan wou'd allow me to serve him as a soldier.—

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: You would fight against the party your father fought for?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: No—but in the forests—or on the desert sands—amongst those slaves who are sent to battle with the wild Indians—there I wou'd go—and earn the boon I ask——or in the mines—

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: Give me your name—I will, at least, present your suit—and, perhaps—

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Sir! do you think it is likely? Joyful hearing!

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p:
Nay, be not too hasty in your hopes—I
cannot answer for my success [Repeats]Your father humbly implores to be released from prison—and, in his stead, you take his chains—or, for the Sultan's service, fight as a slave, or dig in his mines?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Exactly, Sir—that is the petition—I thank you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: You don't know, young man, what it is to dig in mines—or fight against foes, who make their prisoners die by unheard-of tortures.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: You do not know, Sir, what it is—to see a parent suffer.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: Your name, Sir?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Elvirus Casimir.—

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: Your father's?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: The same—one who followed agriculture in the fields of Symria—but, induced by the call of freedom—

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: How? have a care.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: No—his son, by the call of nature, supplicates his freedom.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: The rebel, you find, breaks out.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Silence—silence! he forgives it—don't remind him of it—don't undo my hopes.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: I will serve you if I can.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: And I will merit it—indeed I will—you shall not complain of me—I will be—

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: Retire—I trust you.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Yonder cell contains a female prisoner.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: A female prisoner!

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Without a friend or comforter, she has existed there these many years—nearly fifteen.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: Is it possible!

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Wou'd you wish to see her?

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: If it won't give her pain.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: At least, she'll not resent it—for she seldom complains, except in moans to herself— [Goes to the cell.] Lady, here is one come to vist all the prisoners—please to appear before him.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: I thank you—you speak with reverence and respect to her.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: She has been of some note, though now so totally unfriended—at least, we think she has, from her gentle manners; and our governor is in the daily expectation of some liberal ransom for her, which makes her imprisonment without a hope of release, till that day arrives— [Going to the cell]—Lend me your hand—you are weak.
sp.stage: [He leads her from the cell—she appears faint—and as if the light affected her eyes—Haswell pulls off his hat, and, after a pause—

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: I fear you are not in health, Lady?

div3.stage: [She looks at him solemnly for some time.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Speak—Madam, speak.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: No—not very well.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: Where are your friends? When do you expect your ransom?

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: Never.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: She persists to say so; thinking by that declaration, we shall release her without a ransom.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: Is that your motive?

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: I know no motive for a falsehood.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: I was to blame—pardon me.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Your answers are somewhat prouder than usual.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: They are.— [To Haswell] Forgive me—I am mild with all of these—but from a countenance like yours—I could not bear reproach.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: You flatter me.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: Alas! Sir, and what have I to hope from such a meaness?—You do not come to ransom me.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: Perhaps I do.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: Oh! do not say so—unless—unless—I am not to be deceived—pardon in your turn this suspicion—but when I have so much to hope for—when the sun, the air, fields, woods, and all that wonderous world, wherein I have been so happy, is in prospect; forgive me, if the vast hope makes me fear.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: Unless your ransom is fixed at something beyond my power to give, I will release you.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: Release me! Benevolent!

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: How shall I mark you down in my petition? [Takes out his book.] what name?

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: 'Tis almost blotted from my memory.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: It is of little note—a female prisoner, taken with the rebel party, and in these cells confined for fisteen years.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: Daring which time I have demeaned myself with all humility to my governors—neither have I distracted my fellow prisoners with a complaint that might recall to their memory their own unhappy fate—I have been obedient, patient; and cherished hope to chear me with vain dreams, while despair possess'd my reason.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: Retire—I will present the picture you have given.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: Succeed too—or, never let me see you more—

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: You never shall.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: Or, if you shou'd miscarry in your views [for who forms plans that do not sometimes sail?] I will not reproach you even to myself——no—nor will I suffer much from the disappointment—merely that you may not have, what I suffer, to account for.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: Excellent mind!

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: In this cell—

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: No—take me away—I have enough to do—I dare not see more at present.—

div3.head: SCENE IV. The former Prison Scene.

sp.speaker: Zed.
sp.p: They are coming—I'll stand here in his sight, that, shou'd he miss what I have taken, he'll not suspect me, but suppose it is one who has hid himself.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: What makes you here?—still moping by yourself, and lamenting for your family?— [To Haswell] that man, the most ferocious I ever met with—laments, sometimes even with tears, the separation from his wife and children.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: I am sorry for you, friend; [Zedan looks sullen and morose.] I pity you.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Yes—he had a pleasant hamlet on the neighbouring island—plenty of fruits—clear springs—and wholesome roots—and now complains bitterly of his repasts—sour rice, and muddy water.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: Poor man! bear your sorrows nobly—and as we are alone—no miserable eye to grudge the favour— [Looking round] take this trifle— [Gives money] it will at least make your meals better for a few short weeks—till Heaven may please to favour you with a less sharp remembrance of the happiness you have lost—Farewell.

div3.stage: [Zedan catches hold of him. and taking the pocket-book from his belt, puts it into Haswell's hand.]

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: What's this?

sp.speaker: Zed.
sp.p: I meant to gain my liberty with it—but I will not vex you.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: How came you by it?

sp.speaker: Zed.
sp.p: Stole it—and wou'd have stabb'd you too, had you been alone—but I am glad I did not—Oh! I am glad I did not.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: You like me then?

sp.speaker: Zed.
sp.stage: [Shakes his head and holds his heart.]
sp.p: 'Tis something that I never felt before—it makes me like not only you, but all the world besides—the love of my family was confined to them alone; but this makes me feel I could love even my enemies.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: Oh, nature! grateful! mild! gentle! and forgiving!—worst of tyrants they who, by hard usage, drive you to be cruel!

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: The lights are ready, Sir, through the dark passage— [To Zedan.] Go to your fellows.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: Farewell—we will meet again.

div3.stage: [Zedan exit on one side, Haswell and Keeper exeunt on the other.

div3.head: SCENE I. An Apartment at Sir Luke Tremor's.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: WHY, then Aurelia, (though I never mention'd it to my Lady Tremor) my friend wrote me word, he had reason to suppose your affections were improperly fixed upon a young gentleman in that neighbourhood; and this was his reason for wishing you to leave that place to come hither—and this continual dejection convinces me my friend was not mistaken—answer me—can you say he was?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Why, then, Sir Luke, candidly to confess—

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Nay, no tears—why in tears? for a husband? be comforted—we'll get you one ere long, I warrant.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Dear, Sir Luke, how can you imagine I am in tears because I have not a husband, while you see Lady Tremor every day in tears for the very opposite cause?

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: No matter—women like a husband through pride—and I have known a woman marry from that very motive, even a man she has been ashamed of.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Why, then I dare say, poor Lady Tremor married from pride.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Yes;—and I'll let her know pride is painful.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: But, Sir, her Ladyship's philosophy—

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: She has no philosophy.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Where is his Lordship? What have you done with him?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: He's speaking a word to Mr. Meanright about his passport to England.—Did you mean me, Sir Luke, that had no philosophy? I protest, I have a great deal.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: When? where did you shew it?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Why, when the servant at my Lady Grissei's threw a whole urn of boiling water upon your legs, did I give any proofs of female weakness? did I faint, scream, or even shed a tear?

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: No—no—very true—and while I lay sprawling on the carnet, I could see you fanning and holding the smelling bottle to the Lady of the house, begging her not to make herself uneasy, for that the accident was of no manner of consequence.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Dear Sir, don't be angry;—I am sure her Ladyship spoke as she thought.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: I suppose she did, Miss.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I mean—she thought the accident might be easily got the better of—She thought you might be easily recovered.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: No, indeed, I did not—but I thought Sir Luke had frequently charged me with the want of patience; and that moment, the very thing in the world I cou'd have wished, happened—on purpose to give me an opportunity to prove his accusation false.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p:
Very well, Madam—but did not the
whole company cry shame on your behaviour? did not they say, it was not the conduct of a wife?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Only our particular acquaintance cou'd say so—for the rest of the company, I am sure, did not take me to be your wife—thank Heaven, our appearances never betray that secret—do you think we look like the same flesh and blood?

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: That day, in particular, we did not—for I remember you had been no less than three hours at your toilet.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: And, indeed, Sir Luke, if you were to use milk of roses, and several other little things of that kind, you can't think how much more like a fine gentleman you wou'd look.—Such things as those make, almost, all the difference there is between you and such a gentleman as Mr. Twineall.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: No, pardon me, Madam—a face like mine may use those things—but in Sir Luke's, they wou'd entirely destroy that fine martial appearance— [Sir Luke looks confounded.] which women as well as men admire—for, as valour is the first ornament of our sex—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What are you saying, Mr. Twineall? [Aside.] I'll keep him on this subject if I can.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: I was going to observe, Madam—that the reputation of a General—which puts me in mind, Sir Luke, of an account I read of a battle—
sp.stage: [He crosses over to Sir Luke, who turns up the Stage in the utmost confusion, and steals out of the room.]

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Well, Sir—go on—go on—you were going to introduce—

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: A battle, Madam—but, Sir Luke is gone!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Never mind that, Sir—he generally runs away on these occasions.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: What were you saying, Aurelia, about a husband?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: She did not speak.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: To be sure, Ladies in India do get husbands very quick.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Not always—I am told, Sir Luke—Women of family, [fixing his eyes stedfastly on Lady Tremor.] indeed, may soon enter into the matrimonial state—but the rich men in India, we are told in England, are grown lately very particular with whom they marry, and there is not a man of any repute that will now look upon a woman as a wife, unless she is descended from a good family.
sp.stage: [Looking at Lady Tremor, who walks up the Stage and steals off, just as Sir Luke had done before.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: I am very sorry—very sorry to say, Mr. Twineall, that has not been always the case.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Then I am very sorry too, Sir Luke; for it is as much impossible that a woman, who is not born of a good family, can be—

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: That is just what I say—they cannot be—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Sir Luke, let me tell you—

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: It does not signify telling, my dear,—you have proved it.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Sir, let me tell you—

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: O! O! my dear Madam, 'tis all in vain—there is no such thing—it can't be—there is no pleading against conviction—a person of low birth must, in every particular, be a terrible creature.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: A terrible creature! a terrible creature!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Here comes my Lord Flint—I'll appeal to him.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: My Lord, I was saying, as proof that our great Sultan, who now fills this throne, is no impostor, (as the rebel party wou'd insinuate) no low born man, but of the Royal Stock; his conduct palpably evinces—for, had he not been nobly born, we shou'd have beheld the Plebeian bursting forth upon all occasions [Looking at Lady Tremor] and then, Heaven help all those who had had any dealings with him!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Provoking!

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Sir Luke, is there a doubt of the Emperor's birth and title? he is the real Sultan, depend upon it—it surprises me to hear you talk with the smallest uncertainty.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: O, Sir Luke, I wonder at it too, [Aside to Lord Flint.] and yet, damn me, my Lord, if I have not my doubts.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: I, my Lord? far be it from me! I was only saying what other people said; for my part I never harboured a doubt of the kind.— [Aside.] My head begins to nod, only for that word—pray Heaven, I may die with it on!—I shou'd not like to lose my head—nor shou'd I like to die by a bullet—nor by a small sword—and a cannon ball wou'd be as disagreeable, as any thing, I know—it is very odd—but I never yet could make up my mind, in what manner I shou'd. like to go out of the world.
sp.stage: [During this speech. Twineall is paying court to Lord Flint; they come forward and Sir Luke retires.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Your temerity astonishes me!

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p:
I must own, my Lord, I feel somewhat aukward in saying it to your Lordship—but my own heart—my own conscience—my own sentiments—they are my own—and they are dear to
me.—And so it is—the Sultan does not appear to be [With significance.] that great man some people think him.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Sir, you astonish me—pray what is your name? I have forgotten it.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Twineall, my Lord—the honourable Henry Twineall—your Lordship does me great honour to ask—arrived this morning from England, as your Lordship may remember—in the ship Mercury, my Lord—and all the officers on board speaking with the highest admiration and warmest terms of your Lordship's official character.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Why, then, Mr. Twineall, I am very sorry—

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: And so am I, my Lord, that your sentiments and mine shou'd so far disagree, as I know they do.—I am not unacquainted with your firm adherence to the Emperor—but I am unused to disguise my thoughts—I cou'd not, if I wou'd—I have no little views—no sinister motives—no plots—no intrigues—no schemes of preferment,—and I verily believe that if a large scymitar was now directed at my head—or a large pension directed to my pocket—(in the first case at least) I shou'd speak my mind.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: A dangerous young man this! and I may make something of the discovery.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: It tickles him to the soul, I find.—My Lord, now I begin to be warm on the subject, I feel myself quite agitated—and, from the intelligence which I have heard, even when I was in England,—there is every reason to suppose——exm—exm—exm——

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: What, Sir? what?

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: You understand me.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: No, Sir—explain.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Why, then, there is every reason to suppose—some people are not what they shou'd be—pardon my thoughts, if they are wrong.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: I do pardon your thoughts, with all my heart—but your words, young man, must be answer'd for [Aside.] Lady Tremor, good morning.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: He is going to ruminate on my sentiments, I dare say.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Shall we have your Lordship's company towards the evening? Mr. Haswell will be here; if your Lordship has no objection?

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: How do you know Mr. Haswell will be here?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Because he has just called, in his way to the Palace, and said so—and he has been telling us some very interesting stories too.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Of his moring visits, I suppose—I heard Meanright say he saw him very busy.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Sir Luke and I dine out, my Lord; but we shall return early in the evening.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: I will be here, without fail.—Sir Luke, aword with you if you please— [They come forward.] Mr. Twineall has taken some very improper liberties with the Sultan's name, and I must insist on making him answer for it.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: My Lord, you are extremely welcome [Trembling.] to do whatever your Lordship pleases with any one belonging to me, or to my house—but I hope your Lordship will pay some regard to the master of it.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: O! great regard to the master—and to the mistress also.—But for that gentleman—

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Do what your Lordship pleases.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: I will—and I will make him—

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: If your Lordship does not forget it.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: I shan't forget it, Sir Luke—I have a very good memory, when I please.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: I don't, in the least, doubt it, my Lord—I never did doubt it.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: And I can be very severe too, Sir Luke, when I please.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: I don't, in the least, doubt it, my Lord—I never did doubt it.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: You may depend upon seeing me here in the evening—and then you shall find I have not threatened more than I mean to perform—good morning!

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Good morning, my Lord—I don't in the least doubt it.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: For Heaven's sake, Mr. Twineall, what has birth to do with—

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: It has to do with every thing, Madam—even with beauty—and I wish I may suffer death, if a woman, with all the mental and personal accomplishments of the finest creature in Europe, wou'd to me be of that value, [Snapping his finger.] if lowly born.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: And I sincerely wish every man who visits me was of the same opinion.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: For shame, Mr. Twineall! persons of mean birth ought not to be despised for what it was not in their power to prevent—and if it is a misfortune, you shou'd consider them only as objects of pity.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: And so I do pity them—and so I do—most sincerely—poor creatures.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Aye, now he has mended it finely.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Mr. Twineall, let me tell you—

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p:
My dear—Lady Tremor— [Taking her aside.] let him alone—let him go on—there is something preparing for him he little expects—so let the poor man say and do what he pleases, for the present—it won't last long—for he has offended
my Lord Flint, and, I dare say his Lordship will be able, upon some account or another, to get him imprisoned for life.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Imprisoned! Why not take off his head at once?

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Well, my dear—I am sure I have no objection—and I dare say my Lord will have it done, to oblige you.—Egad, I must make friends with her to keep mine safe.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Do you mean to take him out to dinner with us?

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Yes, my dear, if you approve of it—not else.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: You are grown extremely polite.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Yes, my dear, his Lordship has taught me how to be polite.—Mr. Twineall, Lady Tremor and I are going to prepare for our visit, and I will send a servant to shew you to your apartment, in order to dress, for you will favour us with your company, I hope?

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Certainly, Sir Luke, I shall do myself the honour.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Come this way, Aurelia, I can't bear to look at him.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Nor I to think of him.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p:
If I have not settled my business in this family, I am mistaken—they seem to have but one mind about me.—Devilish clever fellow, egad!—I am the man to send into the world—such a volatile, good-looking scoundrel too! No one suspects me——to be sure I am under some few obligations to my friend for letting me into the different characters of the family—and yet I don't know whether I am obliged to him or not—for if he had not made me acquainted with them—I shou'd soon have had the skill to find them out myshelf.—No; I will not think myshelf under any
obligation to him—it is devilish inconvenient for a gentleman to be under an obligation.

div3.head: SCENE II. The Place. The Sultan discovered with guards and officers attending.
div3.stage: Haswell is conducted in by an officer.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Sir you are summoned to receive our thanks, for the troops restored to health by your kind prescriptions.—Ask a reward adequate to your services.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: Sultan—the reward I ask, is to preserve more of your people still.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: How more? my subjects are in health—no contagion reigns amongst them.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: The prisoner is your subject—there misery—more contagious than disease, preys on the lives of hundreds—sentenced but to confinement, their doom is death.—Immured in damp and dreary vaults, they daily perish—and who can tell but that amongst the many hapless sufferers, there may be hearts, bent down with penitence to Heaven and you, for every slight offence—there may be some amongst the wretched multitude, even innocent victims.—Let me seek them out—let me save them, and you.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Amazement! retract your application—curb this weak pity; and receive our thanks.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: Curb my pity?—and what can I receive in recompence for that soft bond, which links me to the wretched?—and while it sooths their sorrow repays me more, than all the gifts or homage of an empire.——But if repugnant to your plan of government—not in the name of pity—but of justtice.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Justice!——

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: The justice which forbids all but the worst of criminals to be denied that wholesome air the very brute creation freely takes; at least allow them that.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Consider, Sir, for whom you plead—for men, (if not base culprits) yet so misled, so depraved, they are offensive to our state, and deserve none of its blessings.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: If not upon the undeserving,—if not upon the hapless wanderer from the paths of rectitude,—where shall the sun diffuse his light, or the clouds distil their dew? Where shall spring breathe fragrance, or autumn pour its plenty?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Sir, your sentiments, but much more your character, excite my curiosity. They tell me, in our camps, you visited each sick man's bed,—administered yourself the healing draught,—encouraged our savages with the hope of life, or pointed out their better hope in death.—The widow speaks your charities—the orphan lisps your bounties—and the rough Indian melts in tears to bless you.—I wish to ask why you have done all this?—What is it prompts you thus to befriend the wretched and forlorn?

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: In vain for me to explain—the time it wou'd take to tell you why I act thus—

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Send it in writing then.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: Nay, if you will read, I'll send a book, in which is already written why I act thus.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: What book?—What is it called?

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: "The Christian Doctrine." [Haswell bows here with the utmost reverence.] There you will find all I have done was but my duty.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Retire, and leave me alone with the stranger.
sp.stage: [All retire except Haswell and the Sultan. They come forward.]

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p:
Your words recall reflections that distract
me; nor can I bear the pressure on my mind without confessing—I am a Christian.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: A Christian!—What makes you thus assume the apostate?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Misery, and despair.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: What made you a Christian?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: My Arabella,—a lovely European, sent hither in her youth, by her mercenary parents, to sell herself to the prince of all these territories. But 'twas my happy lot, in humble life, to win her love, snatch her from his expecting arms, and bear her far away—where, in peaceful solitude we lived, till, in the heat of the rebellion against the late Sultan, I was forced from my happy home to bear a part.—I chose the imputed rebels side, and fought for the young aspirer.—An arrow, in the midst of the engagement, pierced his heart; and his officers, alarmed at the terror this stroke of fate might cause amongst their troops, urged me (as I bore his likeness) to counterfeit it farther, and shew myself to the soldiers as their king recovered. I yielded to their suit, because it gave me ample power to avenge the loss of my Arabella, who had been taken from her home by the merciless foe, and barbarously murdered.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: Murdered!

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: I learnt so—and my fruitless search to find her since has consirmed the intelligence.—Frantic for her loss, I joyfully embraced a scheme which promised vengeance on the enemy—it prospered,—and I revenged my wrongs and her's, with such unsparing justice on the foe, that even the men who made me what I was, trembled to reveal their imposition; and they find it still their interest to continue it.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: Amazement!

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Nay, they fill my prisons every day with wretches, that dare whisper I am not the real Sultan, but a stranger. The secret, therefore, I myself safely relate in private: the danger is to him who speaks it again; and, with this caution, I trust, it is safe with you.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: It was, without that caution.—Now hear me.—Involved in deeds, in cruelties, which your better thoughts revolt at, the meanest wretch your camps or prisons hold, claims not half the compassion you have excited. Permit me, then, to be your comforter, as I have been theirs.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Impossible!

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: In the most fatal symptoms I have undertaken the body's cure. The mind's disease, perhaps, I'm not less a stranger to—Oh! trust the noble patient to my care.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: How will you begin?

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: Lead you to behold the wretched in their misery, and then shew you yourself in their deliverer.—I have your promise for a boon—'tis this.—Give me the liberty of fix that I shall name, now in confinement, and be yourself a witness of their enlargement.—See joy lighted in the countenance where sorrow still has left its rough remains.—Behold the tear of rapture chase away that of anguish—hear the faultering voice, long used to lamentation, in broken accents, utter thanks and blessings.—Behold this scene, and if you find the medicine ineffectual, dishonour your physician.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: I will behold it.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p:
Come, then, to the governor's house this very night—into that council room so often perverted to the use of the torture; and there, unknown to them as their king, you shall be witness
to all the grateful heart can dictate, and enjoy all that benevolence can taste.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: I will meet you there.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: In the evening?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: At ten precisely.—Guards, conduct the stranger from the palace.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: Thus far advanced, what changes may not be hoped for?

div3.head: SCENE I. An Apartment at Sir Luke's:

sp.speaker: Elvirus.
sp.p: OH my Aurelia! since the time I first saw you—since you left the pleasant spot, where I first beheld you; what distress, what anguish have we known?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Your family?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Yes—and that caused the silence which I hope you have lamented.—I could not wound you with the recital of our misfortunes—and now, only with the sad idea that I shall never see you more, I am come to take my leave.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Is there a chance that we may never meet again?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: There is—and I hope it too—sincerely hope and request it—to see you again, wou'd be again to behold my father pining in misery.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Explain— [A loud rapping at the door.] that is, Sir Luke, and Lady Tremor—what shall I say, shou'd they come hither? they suspect I correspond with some person in the country—who shall I say you are? upon what business can I say you are come?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p:
To avoid all suspicion of my real situation, and to be sure to gain admittance, I put on this habit, and told the servant, when I inquired for you, I was just arrived from England— [She starts.] nay, it was but necessary I should conceal who I
was in this suspicious place, or I might plunge a whose family in the imputed guilt of mine.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Good Heaven!

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: I feared, besides, there was no other means; no likelihood to gain admission—and what, what wou'd I not have sacrificed, rather than left you for ever without a last farewell? think on these weighty causes, and pardon the deception.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: But if they should ask me—

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Say, as I have done—my stay must be so short, it is impossible they shou'd detect me—for I must be back—

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: No matter where—I must be back before the evening—and would almost wish never to see you more—I love you, Aurelia—O, how truly! and yet there is a love more dear, more sacred still.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: You torture me with suspense—Sir Luke is coming this way—what name shall I say, if he asks me?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Glanmore—I announced that name to the servant.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: You tremble.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: The imposition hurts me—and I feel as if I dreaded a detection, though 'tis scarce possible—Sorrows have made a coward of me—even the servant, I thought, looked at me with suspicion—and I was both confounded and enraged.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Go into this apartment; I'll follow you—there we may be safe—and do not hide the smallest circumstance which I may have to apprehend.

sp.speaker: Sir Lake.
sp.p: Abominable! provoking! impertinent! not to be borne!

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Thank Heaven, Sir Luke is so perplexed with some affairs of his own, he may not think of mine.—

div3.stage: Enter Sir Luke, followed by Lady Tremor.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: I am out of all patience—and all temper—did you ever hear of such a compleat impertinent coxcomb? Talk, talk, talk, coutinually! and referring to me on all occasions! Such a man was a brave General—another a great Admiral, and then he must tell a long story about a siege, and ask me if it did not make my bosom glow!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: It had not that effect upon your face, for you were as white as ashes.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke
sp.p: Aye, you did not see yourself, while he was talking of grandfathers and great grandfathers—if you had—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I was not white, I protest.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: No—but you were as red as scarlet.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: And you ought to have resented the insult, if you saw me affected by it—Oh! some men wou'd have given him such a dressing—

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Yes, my dear, if your uncle the frisseur had been alive, he wou'd have given him a dressing, I dare say.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Sir Luke, none of your impertinence; you know I can't nor won't bear it—neither will I wait for Lord Flint's resentment on Mr. Twineall—No, I desire you will tell him to quit this roof immediately.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: No, my dear—no, no—you must excuse me—I can't think of quarrelling with a gentleman in my own house.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Was it your own house to day at dinner when he insulted us? and would quarrel then?

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: No—that was a friend's house—and I make it a rule never to quarrel in my own house—a friend's house—in a tavern—or in the streets.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
Well, then, I would quarrel in my own
house—a friend's house—a tavern—or in the streets—if any one offended me.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: O, my dear, I have no doubt of it—no doubt, in the least.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: But, at present, it shall be in my own house,—and I will tell the gentleman to quit it immediately.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Very well, my dear—pray do.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I suppose, however, I may tell him I have your authority to bid him go?

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Tell him I have no authority—none in the world over you—but that you will do as you like.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I can't tell him so—he won't believe it.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Why not? you often tell me so, and make me believe it too.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Here the gentleman comes—go away for a moment.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: With all my heart, my dear.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I'll give him a few hints, that he must either change his mode of behaviour, or leave us.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: That's right—but don't be too warm—or if he should be very impertinent, or insolent—(i hear Aurelia's voice in the next room) call her, and I dare say she'll come and take your part.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: I positively could pass a whole day upon that stair-case—those reverend faces!—I presume they are the portraits of some of your Ladyship's illustrious ancestors.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Sir! Mr. Twineall—give me leave to tell you—

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: The word illustrious, I find, displeases you—pardon me—I did not mean to make use of so forcible an epithet—I know the delicacy of sentiment, which cannot bear the reflection that a few centuries only shou'd reduce from royalty, one, whose dignified deportment seems to have been formed for that resplendent station.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: The man is certainly mad!——Mr. Twineall—

sp.speaker: Twi
sp.p: Pardon me, Madam—I own I am an enthusiast on these occasions—the dignity of blood—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: You have too much, I am sure—do, have a little taken from you.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Gladly wou'd I lose every drop that fills these plebeian veins, to be enobled by the smallest——

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, take up your abode in some other place.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Your behaviour, Sir—

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: If my friend had not given me the hint, damn me if I shou'd not think her down right angry.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I can scarce contain my rage at being so laugh'd at.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Perhaps you may resent it, Madam—but there is a favour—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: A favour, Sir! is this a time to ask a favour?

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: To an admirer of antiquity, as I am.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Antiquity again!

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: I beg pardon——but——a wig, Ma'am—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: A what?

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: A wig.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
Oh! oh! oh! [Choaking.] this is not to be borne—this is too much—ah! ah! [Sitting
down, and going into fits.] a direct, plain, palpable, and unequivocal attack upon my family—without evasion or palliative.—I can't bear it any longer.—Oh! oh!—

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Bless my soul, what shall I do? what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Maids! maids! go to your mistress—that good-for-nothing fellow is doing her a mischief.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Dear Madam, what is the matter?

div3.stage: Enter Sir Luke, and stands close to the scenes.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh! oh!

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: How do you do now, my dear?

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Upon my word, Sir Luke—

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: O, Sir, no apology—it does not signify—never mind it—I beg you won't put yourself to the trouble of an apology—it is of no kind of consequence.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What do you mean, Sir Luke?

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: To shew proper philosophy, my dear, under the affliction I feel for your distress.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: Take Twineall out of the room.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Mr. Twineall, her Ladyship begs you'll leave the room, till she is a little recovered.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Certainly
sp.stage: [Bows respectfully to ber Ladyship, and exit with Aurelia.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: I thought what you wou'd get by quarrelling—fits—and tears.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
And you know, Sir Luke, if you had quarrelled, you wou'd have been in the same situation. [Rising from her seat.] But, Sir Luke, my
dear, Sir Luke, show yourself a man of courage but on this occasion.—

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: My dear, I wou'd do as much for you as I wou'd for my own life—but damn me if I think I could fight to save that.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Lady Tremor, did the servant say you were very well, or very ill?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh, my Lord, that insolent coxcomb, the honourable Mr. Twineall—

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Oh, I am very glad you put me in mind of it—I dare say I shou'd have forgot it else, notwithstanding I came on purpose.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Forgot what?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: A little piece of paper here, [Pulling out a parchment.] but it will do a great deal—has he offended you?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Beyond bearing.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: I am glad of it, because it gives double pleasure to my vengeance—he is a disaffected person, Madam—boldly told me he doubted the Sultan's right to the throne—I have informed against him, and his punishment is at my option—I may have him imprisoned; shot; sent to the gallies; or his head cut off—but which does your Ladyship chuse?—Which ever you please is at your service.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: O, they are all alike to me; which ever you please, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: What a deal of ceremony!—how cool they are about it.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: And why not cool, Sir; why not cool?

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: O, very true—I am sure it has froze me.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p:
I will go instantly, for fear it shou'd
slip my memory, and put this paper into the hands of proper officers—in the mean time, Sir Luke, if you can talk with your visitor, Mr. Twineall, do—inquire his opinion of the Sultan's rights—ask his thoughts, as if you were commissioned by me—and, while he is revealing them to you, the officers shall be in ambush, surprise him in the midst of his sentiments, and bear him away to—

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: May I presume to inquire how your Ladyship does?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: O, yes—and pray walk in—I am quite recovered.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Lady Tremor, I bid you good day for the present.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Your Lordship won't forget?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: No—depend upon it, I shall remember.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Yes—and make some other people remember too.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Is his Lordship gone? I am very sorry.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: No—don't be uneasy, he'll soon be back.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Mr. Haswell, I am glad to see you?

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: I told her Ladyship I would call in the evening, Sir Luke; and so I have kept my word—I wanted too to speak with my Lord Flint, but he was in such a hurry as he passed me, he wou'd hardly let me ask him how he did.—I hope your Ladyship is well this afternoon.

div3.stage: [Bows to Twineall—Sir Luke exit at the door to Aurelia and Elvirus.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p:
Pardon me, Mr. Haswell, but I almost suspect you heard of her Ladyship's indisposition,
and therefore paid this visit; for I am not to learn your care and attention to all under affliction.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: Has your Ladyship been indisposed then?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: A little—but I am much better.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Surely, of all virtues, charity is the first! it so protects our neighbour!

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: Do not you think, Sir, patience frequently protects him as much?

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Dear Sir—pity for the poor miserable—

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: Is oftener excited than the poor and miserable are aware of.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.stage: [From the room where Aurelia and Elvirus are.]
sp.p: Nay, Sir, I beg you will walk into this apartment—Aurelia, introduce the gentleman to Lady Tremor.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Who has she with her?

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.p: Aurelia!—O! I have not seen her I know not when—and besides my acquaintance with her relations in England, there is a frank simplicity about her that—

div3.stage: Enter Sir Luke, Aurelia, and Elvirus.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: You shou'd have introduced the gentleman before—I assure you, Sir, [To Elvirus.] I did not know, nor shou'd I have known, if I had not accidently come into the room.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: A relation of Aurelia's—a Mr. Glanmore, my dear, just arrived from England; who call'd to pass a few minutes with us, before he sets off to the part of India he is to reside in.
sp.stage: [Elvirus and Aurelia appear in the utmost embarrassment and confusion.

sp.speaker: Lady.
